com.ibm.team.repository.client

Interface ILoginInfo2

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractLoginInfo, IntegratedWindowsLoginInfo, KerberosLoginInfo, KeyStoreLoginInfo, SmartCardLoginInfo, SSLCertificateLoginInfo, UsernameAndPasswordLoginInfo

    public interface ILoginInfo2
    ILoginInfo2 provides the functionality of encapsulating credentials that are custom to the method that is being used and also provides a way to use those credentials by passing those off to ITeamServer.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static java.lang.String AUTH_ID

    • Field Detail

      • AUTH_ID

        static final java.lang.String AUTH_ID
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • getId

        java.lang.String getId()
        Return the Authentication ID. By default, subclasses of AbstractLoginInfo return the name of the class. This ID is used to persist the authentication information for future use.
        Returns:
        authentication type id

      • handleCredentials

        void handleCredentials(com.ibm.team.repository.common.transport.ITeamServer teamServer)
                       throws TeamRepositoryException,
                              SavedPasswordNotObtainedException
        Set the credential on the TeamServer. This call is made usually from ITeamRepository.login(org.eclipse.core.runtime.IProgressMonitor). The credentials set on the TeamServer from this method are used for authentication during a Request to the server.
        Parameters:
        teamServer -
        Throws:
        TeamRepositoryException
        SavedPasswordNotObtainedException

      • hasPassword

        boolean hasPassword()
        Returns true if authentication type requires a password, false otherwise

      • validateLoggedInUser

        boolean validateLoggedInUser(java.lang.String name,
                           java.lang.String userid)
        Validates the Logged in user using the locate credentials that are stored in this LoginInfo. This call is made usually from ITeamRepository.login(org.eclipse.core.runtime.IProgressMonitor) after the user is logged in.
        Parameters:
        name -
        userid -
        Returns:
        true, if the credentials match, false otherwise.

      • isValidLoginInfo

        boolean isValidLoginInfo()
        Return true if this instance of LoginInfo is a valid, false otherwise. Purpose of this method is to validate that the LoginInfo contains all the properties that it needs to execute the handleCredentials(ITeamServer) call.
        Returns:
        True if this instance of LoginInfo is a valid, false otherwise.

      • initialize

        void initialize()
                throws TeamRepositoryException
        Initializies the LoginInfo object so that it can be used for authentication. This call is made from {@link ITeamRepository#login(org.eclipse.core.runtime.IProgressMonitor) right before the steps for authentication are carried out.
        Throws:
        TeamRepositoryException

      • getLoginProperties

        java.util.Properties getLoginProperties()
        Returns the Properties that should be persisted for authentication. This has to be implemented by each subclass of AbstractLoginInfo so the custom properties for each LoginInfo can be persisted.
        Returns:

      • setLoginProperties

        void setLoginProperties(java.util.Properties properties)
        Load the Properties of each LoginInfo that were persisted using the getLoginProperties() method. This has to be implemented by each subclass of AbstractLoginInfo so the custom properties can be loaded.
        Parameters:
        loginProperties - Properties that were persisted using #saveLoginProperties().

      • getSecuredLoginProperties

        java.util.Properties getSecuredLoginProperties()
                                               throws SavedPasswordNotObtainedException
        Secured Properties are properties that need to be stored in an encrypted manner. Properties should be returned in such a manner that they can be passed back to setSecuredLoginProperties(Properties) and it would be able to load the properties back to this object. Example of a secured property would be password in most cases.
        Returns:
        secured properties. Properties are stored in a key=value manner.
        Throws:
        SavedPasswordNotObtainedException

      • setSecuredLoginProperties

        void setSecuredLoginProperties(java.util.Properties properties)
        Set the secured properties on this object. These properties were stored using encryption on the file system. Properties passed are in the same format as what was returned by getSecuredLoginProperties(). Example of a secured property would be password in most cases.
        Parameters:
        properties - Secured properties in key=value manner.

      • successfulLogin

        void successfulLogin()
        Indicate that this login info was successful
